docs.lead_paragraph: Sec. Clinton gave an excellent speech on development today. She has a longtime interest in poverty issues, and President Obama's mother was a pioneer in microfinance, yet so far the Obama administration hasn't been particularly engaged in global poverty issues. It took forever, after all, to get an administrator for USAID, the aid agency. In contrast, President Bush never seemed very interested in global poverty, but he left a quite impressive legacy there -- with Pepfar, the AIDS effort; the President's Malaria Initiative; and his Millennium Challenge Corporation directing aid to countries with good governance.
docs.abstract: Sec. Clinton gave an excellent speech today on development.

docs.lead_paragraph: It's happened again. Just the other day I got to talking with a dedicated Democrat about 2006 and 2008. Within a few minutes the appearance of two names and the absence of a third reminded me of why the party may very well blow it despite the fact that every morning brings news of a further drop in the president's ratings and a growing discontent with the administration's management of everything - from the Iraq War, to the environment, the Katrina disaster, foreign-owned ports, huge budget deficits, prescription drug benefits, corporate scandals, trigger-happy vice-presidents, authorized torture, inhumane prisons, Halliburton profiteering, domestic spying, strategic leaking, illegal lobbying practices, indicted congressmen, indicted administration officials, rising energy costs, under-funded education mandates, huge trade imbalances, know-nothing science policies and disinformation campaigns. This week's revelation: the existence (or so Seymour Hersh maintains) of a secret plan to bomb Iran.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: That Hillary Rodham Clinton, nor many a Republican, did not see reason to object in the late 1990's to a Chinese government company's running the Port of Long Beach does not preclude them from evolving in their views in light of subsequent developments.
docs.abstract: Letter from former Hillary Clinton staff assistant Christopher A Stratton says evolution of Clinton's views is rooted in hard-won common sense; says operation and security of ports should be governmental function (March 12 David Brooks Op-Ed column)

docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal district judge considered today the legality of Hillary Rodham Clinton's influential role in formulating health policy for the nation. At times it seemed that old laws had not caught up with the new realities of the wife of the President serving as his top official adviser on the future of health care in America.
